titleStmt.title: The extended VIKOR method for multi-attribute group decision making with triangular intuitionistic fuzzy numbers

analytic.title: The extended VIKOR method for multi-attribute group decision making with triangular intuitionistic fuzzy numbers

biblStruct.note: Received 10 February 2013 Received in revised form 29 June 2013 Accepted 30 June 2013

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Multi-attribute group decision making Triangular intuitionistic fuzzy numbers Shannon entropy measure Evidence theory VIKOR method

div.p: Triangular intuitionistic fuzzy numbers (TIFNs) are a special intuitionistic fuzzy set (IFS) on a real number set, which are very useful for decision makers (DMs) to depict their fuzzy preference information. In this work, we investigate multiple attribute group decision-making (MAGDM) problems in which the ratings of alternatives are expressed with TIFNs, and the weights of the attributes and DMs are completely unknown. Firstly, the crisp weighted possibility mean of TIFNs is defined, and the Hamming distance and Euclidean distance for TIFNs are defined based on Hausdorff distance. The triangular intuitionistic fuzzy weighted average (TIF-WA) operator is developed. Then, the weights of attributes are calculated by applying Shannon entropy measure and the weights of DMs are determined objectively combining the evidence theory with Bayes approximation. The individual decision matrixes for all DMs are aggregated into the group decision matrix by using the TIF-WA operator. Thereby, the classic Vlsekriterijumska Optimizacija I Kompromisno Resenje (VIKOR) method is extended for solving the MAGDM with TIFNs. Finally, the ranking order of alternative is given according to the closeness of alternative with respect to the ideal solution. The personnel selection example verifies the effectiveness of the proposed method.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Multiple attribute decision making (MADM) problems often occur in a variety of practical problems, such as economic analysis, strategic planning, human resource management and supply chain management. However, since the economic society becomes more and more complex, it becomes more and more difficult for individual decision maker (DM) or expert to account for all the aspects of the associated problems accurately. In order to make the decision results more reasonable, multiple DMs are required to make decision together for many complex decision processes. Thus, the multiple attribute group decision making (MAGDM) problems appear [1].

Due to the influences of subjective and objective factors, it is not easy for DMs to give the accurate evaluation on complex things in practical decision problems. There usually exist some hesitations for DMs to assess the fuzzy and uncertain quantities. The intuitionistic fuzzy numbers (IFNs) [2], which are the special intuitionistic fuzzy set (IFS) [3] defined on the real number set, are just the suitable tools to express these ill-known quantities. Triangular intuitionistic fuzzy number (TIFN) [2,[4][5][6][7], trapezoidal intuitionistic fuzzy number (TrIFN) [8][9][10][11][12][13][14][15][16], and interval-valued trapezoidal intuitionistic fuzzy number (IVTrIFN) [17,18] are the three kinds of typical IFNs. They extend the discourse universe of IFS from the discrete set to continuous set, they are also the extension of fuzzy numbers [8,9]. Compared with the definition of IFS, TIFN makes the membership and non-membership no longer just relative to a fuzzy concept of ''excellent'' or ''good'' by adding the triangular fuzzy number (TFN) (a, b, c). TIFNs can express different dimension decision information and reflect DMs' information more accurately. For example, in personnel selection the moral character of a candidate may be evaluated as TIFNs ((6.2,8.1,9.2); 0.7,0.2), which means that the assessment value of the candidate is between 6.2 and 9.2, the most possible value is about 8.1 with the maximum satisfaction degree 0.7, the minimum dissatisfaction degree 0.2, and the hesitation degree 0.1. Therefore, applying TIFNs to decision making field would have important theoretical value and practical significance.

At present, there are some progresses about IFNs in the applications of MADM and MAGDM. Shu et al. [4] firstly defined the concept of the TIFN in a similar way to that of the fuzzy number and developed an algorithm for intuitionistic fuzzy fault tree analysis. Li [2] pointed out and corrected some errors in the definition of the four arithmetic operations over the TIFNs in [4]. Li et al. [5] defined the values and ambiguities of the membership and non-membership degrees for TIFNs as well as the value-index and ambiguity-index. Hereby the method based on value and ambiguity was developed to rank TIFNs, which was applied to solve MADM problems with TIFNs. Li [6] discussed the concept of TIFN in depth and ranking method based on the ratio of the value index to the ambiguity index, and applied them to solve the MADM problems. Nan et al. [7] defined the ranking order relations of TIFNs, which were applied to matrix games with payoffs of TIFNs.

As the extension of the TIFNs, Wang [8] introduced the concepts of TrIFN and IVTrIFN. Wang and Zhang [9] investigated the weighted arithmetic averaging operator and weighted geometric averaging operator on TrIFNs and their applications to MADM problems. Wei [10] developed some arithmetic aggregation operators with TrIFNs and applied to MAGDM problems. Wan and Dong [11] defined the expectation and expectant score, ordered weighted aggregation operator and hybrid aggregation operator for TrIFNs and employed to MAGDM. Ye [12] developed the expected value method for intuitionistic trapezoidal fuzzy multicriteria decisionmaking problems. Ye [13] proposed the MAGDM method using vector similarity measures for TrIFNs. Wu and Cao [14] developed some families of geometric aggregation operators with TrIFNs, which were applied to MAGDM problems. Zhang et al. [15] proposed a gray relational projection method for MAGDM based on TrIFNs. Wan [16] developed power average operators of TrIFNs and applied to MAGDM. Wan [17] firstly defined some operational laws of IVTrIFNs and developed the weighted arithmetical average operator and weighted geometrical average operator for IVTrIFNs. An approach to ranking IVTrIFNs is presented based on the score function and accurate function. The MAGDM method using IV-TrIFNs is then proposed. Wan [18] defined the Hamming and Euclidean distances for IVTrIFNs and proposed the fractional programming method for the MADM problems using IVTrIFNs.

The Vlsekriterijumska Optimizacija I Kompromisno Resenje (VI-KOR) method was developed by Opricovic and Tzeng [19] for multi-attribute optimization of complex problem, which focuses on ranking and selecting from a set of alternatives with conflicting attributes. Compared with TOPSIS, VIKOR cannot only consider group utility maximization and individual regret minimization, but also can fully reflect the DM's subjective preferences [20,21]. However, the existing researches about TIFNs mainly discussed the ranking method and aggregation operators, there was no investigation on introducing classic VIKOR method to solve the MAGDM problems with TIFNs. To overcome this drawback, the aim of this paper is to objectively determine the weights of DMs and attributes and then extend the classic VIKOR to solve the MAGDM problems with TIFNs. The motivation and main features of the proposed method in this paper are summarized as follows:

(i) Although [7,[9][10][11] studied the MADM with TIFNs and TrIFNs, there is no research on MAGDM with TIFNs. The existing MADM methods with TIFNs cannot directly be applied to the MAGDM with TIFNs. As aforementioned, the MAGDM problems often happen under the intuitionistic fuzzy environment. Therefore, the MAGDM problems with TIFNs are of great importance for science research and real application. (ii) In the MADM with TIFNs [2,[4][5][6], the attribute weights are usually known in priori or given artificially, which cannot avoid the subjective randomness. In addition, due to the different background, expertise and experience, the importance of DMs should be taken into consideration in the process of group decision making. This paper not only objectively determines the attribute weights based on Shannon entropy theory, but also determines the DM weights combining the evidence theory and Bayes approximation, which can effectively reduce the subjective randomness.

(iii) In the classical VIKOR [19], the attribute weights and DM weights are also given in advance. Furthermore, the classical VIKOR is only appropriate for the decision making problems with the crisp assessment information and cannot solve the MAGDM with TIFNs. This paper utilizes the defined Hamming or Euclidean distance of TIFNs to replace the distance of real numbers and then calculates the group utility value and individual regret value. Thus, the extended VIKOR method is proposed for solving the MAGDM problems with TIFNs. (iv) Though Wan [16][17][18] investigated the decision methods with IFNs, the IFNs discussed in Wan [16] are TrIFNs, that in Wan [17,18] are IVTrIFNs, whereas that in this paper are TIFNs.

Hence, the research objects of this paper are completely different from that in Wan [16][17][18]. In addition, Wan [16] developed MAGDM method with TrIFNs based on the power average operators. Wan [17] developed MAGDM method with IVTrIFNs based on the weighted arithmetical and geometrical average operators. Wan [18] proposed the fractional programming method for MADM with IVTrIFNs. This paper proposed the extended VIKOR method for MAGDM with TIF-Ns. Therefore, the decision principle of this paper is also significantly different from that of Wan [16][17][18]. (v) Compared with the similar methods, the proposed method in this paper can maximize the group utility and minimize the individual regret simultaneously, which make the decision result more reasonable. The DMs can adjust the coefficient of decision mechanism to reflect the different importance of group utility and individual regret, which greatly enhances the flexibility of the proposed method. Moreover, though the proposed method is developed to solve MAGDM with TIFNs, it also can be used to solve MADM with TIFNs.

The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, the crisp weighted possibility mean, and the Hamming distance and Euclidean distance for TIFNs are defined as well as the triangular intuitionistic fuzzy weighted average (TIF-WA) operator. Section 3 presents MAGDM problems with TIFNs, determines the weights of attributes and DMs objectively, and then proposes the extended VIKOR method. A personnel selection example and comparison analyzes are given in Section 4. Some conclusions are made in Section 5.

div.head: Triangular intuitionistic fuzzy numbers
div.p: In this section, we give some concepts of TIFNs, including the definition, operation laws, crisp weighted possibility means, weighted average operator, and distances of TIFNs.

div.head: The definition and operation laws of TIFNs

The f weighted upper possibility mean m l ðãÞ of membership function is nothing else but the f weighted upper possibility weighted average of the maximum of the a-cut set.

( 9) and (10) that It can be seen that the g weighted lower possibility mean m m ðãÞ of non-membership function is nothing else but the g weighted lower possibility weighted average of the minimum of the b-cut set. The g weighted upper possibility mean m m ðãÞ of non-membership function is nothing else but the g weighted upper possibility weighted average of the maximum of the b-cut set. Definition 6. For a TIFN ã ¼ ðða; a; aÞ; xã; uãÞ, the f weighted possibility mean of membership function and g weighted possibility mean of non-membership function are respectively defined as follows:
div.formula: m m ð ãÞ ¼ Z 1 uã g Pos ã 6 a l b h i a l b db ¼ Z 1 uã gðbÞa l b db; m m ðãÞ ¼ Z 1 uã g Pos ã P a u b h i a u b db ¼ Z 1 uã gðbÞa u b db:
m l ð ãÞ ¼ 1 2 ½m l ð ãÞ þ m l ð ãÞð11Þ
div.p: and
div.formula: m m ðãÞ ¼ 1 2 ½m m ðãÞ þ m m ðãÞ:ð12Þ
div.p: If the TIFN ã ¼ ðða; a; aÞ; xã; uãÞ degenerates to the triangular fuzzy number ða; a; aÞ, i.e., xã ¼ 1 and uã ¼ 0, then, m l ðãÞ (or m m ðãÞÞ is just the f weighted possibility mean of fuzzy number defined in Definition 2 of [22] (see pp. 365). Therefore, the f weighted possibility mean of fuzzy number defined in [22] is just a special case of that defined in this paper.

Obviously, m l ðãÞ synthetically reflects the information on every membership degree and may be regarded as a central value that represents from the membership function point of view. Likewise, m m ðãÞ synthetically reflects the information on every non-membership degree and may be regarded as a central value that represents from the non-membership function point of view. 4), ( 7) and ( 8), we have

m l ð ãÞ ¼ 1 3 ð a þ 2aÞxã;ð16Þ
m m ð ãÞ ¼ 1 3 ð2a þ aÞð1 À uãÞ;ð17Þ
m m ð ãÞ ¼ 1 3 ð2a þ aÞð1 À uãÞ:ð18Þ
div.p: Further, by Eqs. ( 11) and ( 12), we have

m m ðãÞ ¼ 1 6 ða þ 4a þ aÞð1 À uãÞ:ð20Þ

div.p: Thus, for TIFN ã; m l ðãÞ and m m ðãÞ can be formed the weighted possibility mean interval as follows:
div.formula: ½m l ð ãÞ; m m ð ãÞ ¼ 1 6 ða þ 4a þ aÞxã; 1 6 ða þ 4a þ aÞð1 À uãÞ ! : Remark 1.
div.p: The weighting functions f and g can be chosen as several forms, for example, f ðaÞ ¼ ðn þ 1Þa n =ðxãÞ n ða 2 ½0; xãÞ and gðbÞ ¼ ðn þ 1Þð1 À bÞ n =ð1 À uãÞ n ðb 2 ½uã; 1Þ;
respectively.

In real-life application, the weighting functions f and g can be selected according to the real need of the decision problems and the preferences of DMs. Hence, the weighted possibility mean of membership (non-membership) function not only reflects the information on every membership (non-membership) degree and represents a central value of membership (non-membership) function, but also exhibits great flexibility and facility for different preferences of DMs. In what follows, the weighting functions f and g are respectively chosen as Eqs. ( 13) and ( 14) for computation convenience.
Definition 7 [23]. Let b ¼ ½b l ; b u be any interval number. The C-OWA operator could be used to defuzzify b into accurate number hð bÞ as follows:
div.formula: hð bÞ ¼ C À OWA qðyÞ ð bÞ ¼ Z 1 0 dqðyÞ dy b u À yðb u À b l Þ h i dy;ð21Þ
div.p: where q(y) is a basic unit-interval monotonic function (BUM), satisfying the conditions: q(0) = 0, q(1) = 1, and q(x) P q(y) if x P y. The choice of BUM function q(y) is a reflection of the DM's risk preference.

Remark 2. There are several defuzzification methods to defuzzify fuzzy numbers, but no unique best approach exists. Since the above method sufficiently considers the DM's risk preference and increases our capability for modeling DM's preferences in comparing fuzzy numbers, it is more reasonable and consistent with the real-life situation. For example, if q(y) = y r (r > 0), then hðãÞ
div.formula: ¼ 1 6 ða þ 4a þ aÞ½ð1 À uãÞ þ rxã=ð1 þ rÞ. For different r, we have hð ãÞ ¼ 1 6 ða þ 4a þ aÞð1 À uãÞ; if r ! 0 1 18 ða þ 4a þ aÞ½2ð1 À uãÞ þ xã; if r ¼ 1 2 1 12 ða þ 4a þ aÞð1 À uã þ xãÞ; if r ¼ 1 1 18 ða þ 4a þ aÞ½ð1 À uãÞ þ 2xã; if r ¼ 2 1 6 ða þ 4a þ aÞxã; if r ! 1: 8 > > > > > > > > < > > > > > > > > :ð23Þ
div.p: A usual defuzzification method for interval is taking the median. For the weighted possibility mean interval ½m l ðãÞ; m m ðãÞ, the median is 1 12 ða þ 4a þ aÞð1 À uã þ xãÞ which is just the special case of r = 1 in Eq. (23). Moreover, there are several different BUM functions which can be used in Eq. ( 22). Thus, compared with the taking median method and existing other methods, the defuzzification method of Definition 8 is of university.

div.head: The triangular intuitionistic fuzzy weighted average operator
div.p: Definition 9. Let ãj ðj ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; nÞ be a collection of TIFNs. Let TIF-WA:
div.formula: X n ? X, if TIF À WAð ã1 ; ã2 ; . . . ; ãn Þ ¼ X n j¼1 w j ãj ;
div.p: where X is the set of all TIFNs, w j is the weight of ãj satisfying that w j 2 [0, 1] (j = 1, 2, . . ., n) and P n j¼1 w j ¼ 1, then the TIF-WA is called the triangular intuitionistic fuzzy weighted average operator.
Theorem 1. Let ãj ðj ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; nÞ be a collection of TIFNs, then their aggregated value by using the TIF-WA operator is also a TIFN and
div.formula: TIF À WAðã 1 ;ã 2 ;...;ã n Þ ¼ X n j¼1 w j a j ; X n j¼1 w j a j ; X n j¼1 w j a j ! ;min j fxã j g;max j fuã j g ! :ð24Þ
div.p: Proof. The proof of Theorem 1 can be easily proven using mathematical induction for n according to Definition 2. h
The TIF-WA operator has some desirable properties, such as idempotency, boundedness, and monotonicity.
div.formula: If Z = R, U and O are closed intervals, i.e., U = [u 1 , u 2 ] and O = [o 1 , o 2 ], then d(U, O) = max{ju 1 À o 1 j, ju 2 À o 2 j}.
div.p: Based on the Hausdorff distance of Definition 10, the Hamming and Euclidean distances of TIFNs can be defined as follows.

Definition 11. Let ã ¼ ðða; a; aÞ; x 1 ; u 1 Þ and b ¼ ððb; b; bÞ; x 2 ; u 2 Þ be two TIFNs. The Hamming distance and Euclidean distance between them are respectively defined as follows: Proof. Obviously, Eqs. ( 25) and ( 26) meet the properties of nonnegative and symmetry. The only thing we need to do is to prove the triangular inequality.
div.formula: d h ð ã; bÞ ¼ 1 3 ðja À bj þ ja À bj þ j a À bjÞ þ maxðjx 1 À x 2 j; ju 1 À u 2 jÞ;ð25Þ
d e ð ã; bÞ ¼ ffiffiffi 1 3 r ða À bÞ 2 þ ða À bÞ 2 þ ð a À bÞ 2 h þ maxðjx 1 À x 2 j 2 ; ju 1 À u 2 j 2 Þ i 1=2 :ð26Þ
If x 1 = x 2 = 1, u 1 = u 2 = 0, then TIFNs ã ¼ ðða; a; aÞ; x 1 ; u 1 Þ and b ¼ ð½b; b; b; x 2 ; u 2 Þ
div.p: Since jx 1 À x 3 j 6 jx 1 À x 2 j + jx 2 À x 3 j, ju 1 À u 3 j 6 ju 1 À u 2 j + ju 2 À u 3 j, we have In this section, we give the description of MAGDM problems with TIFNs and determine the attribute weights and DM weights. An extended VIKOR method is then proposed for solving the MAG-DM with TIFNs.
div.formula: maxðjx 1 À x 3 j;u 1 À u 3 jÞ 6 maxðjx 1 À x 2 j;ju 1 À u 2 jÞ þ maxðjx 2 À x 3 j;ju 2 À u 3 jÞ; ja À cj 6 ja À bj þ jb À cj; ja À cj 6 ja À bj þ jb À cj; j a À cj 6 j a À bj þ j b À cj:

div.head: The description of MAGDM problems with TIFNs
div.p: The MAGDM problems discussed in this paper can be described as follows:

Suppose that there are p DMs {D 1 , D 2 , . . ., D p }, they evaluate z noninferior alternatives {A 1 , A 2 , . . ., A z }, each alternative is assessed on n attributes {a 1 , a 2 , . . ., a n }. Let w = (w 1 , w 2 , . . ., w n ) T be the weight vector of attributes, where w j is weight of the attribute a j satisfying that w j 2 [0, 1] (j = 1, 2, . . ., n) and T are unknown, which need to be determined.
div.formula: P n j¼1 w j ¼ 1. Let V = (v 1 , v 2 , . . ., v p ) T be the weight vector of DMs, where v k is the weight of DM D k satisfying that v k 2 [0, 1] (k = 1, 2, . . ., p) and P p k¼1 v k ¼ 1. Both w = (w 1 , w 2 , . . ., w n ) T and V = (v 1 , v 2 , . . ., v p )
div.p: Assume that the ratings of alternatives on attributes are represented using TIFNs by DMs. Namely, the rating of alternative A i on an attribute a j given by DM D k is a TIFN ãk
div.formula: ij ¼ a k ij ; a k ij ; a k ij ; x k a ij ; u k a ij .
div.p: Thus, the MAGDM problems with TIFNs can be expressed concisely in the matrix format as e A k ¼ ãk ij zÂn ðk ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; pÞ.

div.head: Determination of attribute weights based on Shannon entropy theory
div.p: Since the attribute weight vector w = (w 1 , w 2 , . . ., w n ) T is unknown, we first determine the individual attribute weight vector
div.formula: w k ¼ w k 1 ; w k 2 ; . . . ; w k n À Á
div.p: given by DM D k (k = 1, 2, . . ., p), and then integrate these weight vectors to obtain the collective attribute weight vector w = (w 1 , w 2 , . . ., w n ) T .

Entropy measure can be used to determine the attribute weight according to the amount of information implied in each attribute. The less the amount of information is, the bigger the entropy is, vice versa. Hence, this paper applies Shannon entropy to determine the individual attribute weight vector w k ¼ w k 1 ; w k 2 ; . . . ; w k n À Á ðk ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; pÞ. According to Eq. ( 23), the fuzzy decision matrix e A k ¼ ãk ij zÂn can be defuzzified into the crisp weighted possibility mean matrix
div.formula: H k ¼ h k ij zÂn
div.p: , where
div.formula: h k ij ¼ 1 6 a k ij þ 4a k ij þ a k ij 1 À u k a ij þ rx k a ij h i =ð1 þ rÞ:ð27Þ
Let x k ij ¼ h k ij =h kþ j ; j 2 J b h kÀ j =h k ij ; j 2 J c 8 < :ð28Þ
div.p: where h kþ j
div.formula: ¼ max h k ij ji ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; z n o and h kÀ j ¼ min h k ij ji ¼ 1;2;...;z n o ;
div.p: J b and J c denote the subscript sets of benefit and cost attributes, respectively.
In order to determine the weights of attributes objectively using Shannon entropy measure, the matrix
div.formula: H k ¼ h k ij zÂn should be nor- malized as N k ¼ n k ij zÂn
div.p: , which is called the normalized crisp weighted possibility mean matrix, where
div.formula: n k ij ¼ x k ij X z i¼1 , x k ij :ð29Þ
div.p: For the matrix N k , the entropy value e k j of the attribute a j given by DM D k can be calculated as follows:
div.formula: e k j ¼ À 1 ln z X z i¼1 n k ij ln n k ij ðj ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; n; k ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; pÞ:ð30Þ
div.p: Therefore, the weight w k j of the attribute a j given by DM D k can be obtained as follows:
div.formula: w k j ¼ 1 À e k j . X n j¼1
div.p: 1 À e k j ðj ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; n; k ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; pÞ: ð31Þ

div.head: Determination of DM weights combining the evidence theory with Bayes approximation
div.p: In this section, we propose a new approach to determining DM weights combining the evidence theory with Bayes approximation.

Let H = {A 1 , A 2 , . . ., A z } be the identification framework, where A i represents the ith identifiable object. Let P(H) be the power set of H which consists of 2 z elements. A basic probability assignment (BPA) is called the mass function m(Á): P(H) ? [0, 1] such that m(/) = 0 and P A # H mðAÞ ¼ 1, where / is the empty set and the mass m(A) represents how strongly the evidence supports the object A.

Dempster-Shafer combinational rule [25] can be used only if the frame of discernment is fine enough to discern all relevant interaction of the evidence to be combined. Voobraak [26] introduced Bayes approximation of mass function for achieving possible computational savings in the applications of Dempster-Shafer by distributing mass m to a subset of H over its elements. The Bayes approximation m of mass function m can be computed as follows:
div.formula: mðAÞ ¼ X A # B mðBÞ X C # H ½mðCÞ Á jCj; if A is a singleton , 0; else 8 > < > :ð32Þ
div.p: For the MAGDM problems, if we consider the alternatives as the identifiable objects, then the set of alternatives {A 1 , A 2 , . . ., A z } can be viewed as the identification framework H. The ratings of alter-
div.formula: natives on attributes n k ij in N k ¼ n k ij zÂn
div.p: can be viewed as the evidence bodies. Let m k j ðA i Þ be the evidence body of the identifiable object A i on attribute a j given by DM D k . Thus, we have
div.formula: m k j ðA i Þ ¼ n k ij
div.p: Considered the reliability (i.e., importance) w k j of attribute a j , the weighted attribute evidence body of alternative A i on attribute a j can be calculated as follows [27,28]:
div.formula: m 0k j ðA i Þ ¼ w k j m k j ðA i Þ;ð34Þ
m 0k j ðHÞ ¼ 1 À X z i¼1 m 0k j ðA i Þ ¼ 1 À w k j X m i¼1 m k j ðA i Þ:ð35Þ
div.p: Using Eq. (32), we can obtain the Bayes approximation m 0k j ðA i Þ of mass function m 0k j ðA i Þ. Combined combinational rule with Bayes approximation [26], the n Bayes approximation m 0k j ðA i Þ ðj ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; nÞ can be aggregated into the individual overall evidence body m k (A i ) of alternative A i for DM D k as follows:
div.formula: m k ðA i Þ ¼ 0; if A i ¼ / 1 K X \X i ¼A i Y n j¼1 m 0k j ðX i Þ; if A i -/ 8 > < > : ði ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; zÞ;ð36Þ
div.p: where X i 2 H is a singleton and K ¼
div.formula: P \X i -/
div.p: Q n j¼1 m 0k j ðX i Þ denotes the degree of conflict between evidence bodies.

Let m k = {m k (A 1 ), m k (A 2 ), . . ., m k (A z )} be the set of evidence bodies m k (A i ) (i = 1, 2, . . ., z). For any m q and m t , the distance between m q and m t can be defined as follows [29]:
div.formula: dðm q ; m t Þ ¼ ffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi ffi 1 2 ð½M q ; M q þ ½M t ; M t À 2½M q ; M t Þ r ;ð37Þ
div.p: where vector M l ¼ ðm l ðA 1 Þ; m l ðA 2 Þ; . . . ; m l ðA z ÞÞ T ; ðl ¼ q; tÞ; A i 2 H;
½M q ; M t is the scalar product defined as:
div.formula: ½M q ; M t ¼ X z i¼1 X z j¼1 ½m q ðA i Þm t ðA j Þd ij ;ð38Þ
where d ij ¼ jA i \A j j jA i [A j j ði; j ¼ 1; . . . ; 2 z Þ.
div.p: Thus, we can formulate the evidence distance matrix D E = (d(m q , m t )) zÂz .
The similarity between m q and m t can be calculated as follows:
div.formula: sðm q ; m t Þ ¼ 1 À dðm q ; m t Þ ðq; t ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; pÞ;ð39Þ
div.p: which are formed into the evidence similarity matrix S E = (s(m q , m t )) zÂz .

It is obvious that the smaller the distance is, the better the similarity is. Let Sup (m k ) be the support degree of m k , which is the degree of evidence body m k supported by other evidence bodies. Sup (m k ) is the function of the similarity which can be expressed as follows:
div.formula: Supðm k Þ ¼ X p t¼1;t-k sðm k ; m t Þ ðk ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; pÞ:ð40Þ
div.p: The reliability degree crd(m k ) of m k is defined as:
div.formula: crdðm k Þ ¼ Supðm k Þ= X p t¼1 Supðm t Þ ðk ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; pÞ:ð41Þ
div.p: It is easy to see that P p k¼1 crdðm k Þ ¼ 1, the credibility degree crd(m k ) can be viewed as the importance (or weight) of m k given by DM D k , and thus can be used to measure the importance of DM D k . Hence, the weight vector V = (v 1 , v 2 , . . ., v p ) T of DMs can be obtained, where
div.formula: v k ¼ crdðm k Þ ¼ Supðm k Þ= X p t¼1 Supðm t Þ ðk ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; pÞ:ð42Þ
div.p: In group decision making, some DMs will support each other if their judgments are almost consistent. Thus, these DMs should have higher credibility and should be allocated higher weights. On the contrary, a few DMs maybe have the different views with the most DMs. In order to minimize their adverse effects on the actual verdict, such DMs should be allocated lower weights, their views are considered to be a noise, heterogeneous or isolated point. Just motivated by this idea, we develop the above approach to determining DMs' weights, which is accordance with the actual results based on knowledge in logic.

div.head: The extended VIKOR method for MAGDM with TIFNs
div.p: On the basis of the above analysis, we extend the classic VIKOR method for solving the MAGDM problems with TIFNs. The main steps are summarized as follows:
Step 1.
For the fuzzy decision matrix e A k ¼ ãk ij zÂn ðk ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; pÞ, calculate the crisp weighted possibility mean matrix H k ¼ h k ij zÂn by Eq. ( 27);
Step 2. Compute the individual weight vectors of attributes w k ¼ w k 1 ; w k 2 ; . . . ; w k n À Á T ðk ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; pÞ given by DM D k using Eqs.
Step 3. Determine the weight vector of DMs V = (v 1 , v 2 , . . ., v p ) T by Eqs. ( 33)-(42);
Step 4. The collective weight vector of attributes w = (w 1 , w 2 , . . ., w n ) T is calculated as follows:
div.formula: w j ¼ X p k¼1 v k w k j ðj ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; nÞ:ð43Þ
div.p: Step 5. Construct the TIFN group decision matrix; Used the TIF-WA operator (i.e., Eq. ( 24)), the individual decision matrixes e A k ¼ ãk ij zÂn ðk ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; pÞ can be aggregated into the
div.formula: group decision matrix e G ¼ ðg ij Þ zÂn , where gij ¼ ððg 1i ða j Þ; g 2i ða j Þ; g 3i ða j ÞÞ; x g ij ; u g ij Þ ¼ TIF À WA ã1 ij ; ã2 ij ; . . . ; ãp ij ¼ X p k¼1 v k ãk ij ¼ X p k¼1 v k a k ij ; X p k¼1 v k a k ij ; X p k¼1 v k a k ij ! ; min 16k6p x k ãij n o ; max 16k6p u k ãij n o ! :ð44Þ
div.p: Step 6. Normalize the group decision matrix e G ¼ ðg ij Þ zÂn ; In order to eliminate the effect of different physical dimensions on the final decision results, the matrix e G ¼ ðg ij Þ zÂn should be normalized into e R ¼ ðr ij Þ zÂn , where rij ¼ ððr 1i ða j Þ; r 2i ða j Þ; r 3i ða j ÞÞ; xr ij ; ur ij Þ with xr ij ¼ xg ij , ur ij ¼ ug ij and r li ða j Þ ¼ max j fg 3i ða j Þg À g 4Àl;i ða j Þ max j fg 3i ða j Þg À min j fg 1i ða j Þg ðl ¼ 1; 2; 3 and j 2 J c Þ; ð45Þ and r li ða j Þ ¼ g li ða j Þ À min j fg 1i ða j Þg max j fg 3i ða j Þg À min j fg 1i ða j Þg ðl ¼ 1; 2; 3 and j 2 J b Þ; ð46Þ respectively, the subscript 4 À l of g 4Àl, i (a j ) is to ensure that the normalized results satisfy r 1i (a j ) 6 r 2i (a j ) 6 r 3i (a j ), i.e., rij is still a TIFN.
Step
Step 8. Calculate the group utility value and individual regret value of each alternative;

Applied the Hamming or Euclidean distance (i.e., Eq. ( 25) or Eq. ( 26)), the group utility value S(A i ) and individual regret value R(A i ) for alternative A i can be respectively calculated as follows:
div.formula: SðA i Þ ¼ X n j¼1 w j d ãþ j ; rij d ãþ j ; ãÀ j ;ð49Þ
RðA i Þ ¼ max 16j6n w j d ãþ j ; rij d ãþ j ; ãÀ j 8 < : 9 = ; ;ð50Þ
div.p: where d is the Hamming distance d h or Euclidean distance d e .

Step 9. Calculate the degree of closeness of each alternative; Let S + = min 16i6z {S(A i )}, S À = max 16i6z {S(A i )}, R + = min 16i6z {-R(A i )}, and R À = max 16i6z {R(A i )}. The closeness of alternative A i to the ideal solution can be calculated as follows:
div.formula: Q ðA i Þ ¼ k SðA i Þ À S þ S À À S þ þ ð1 À kÞ RðA i Þ À R þ R À À R þ ði ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; zÞ;ð51Þ
div.p: where the coefficient of decision mechanism k is the weight of the strategy of maximum group utility, and 1 À k is the weight of individual regret, k 2 [0, 1].

Step 10. Ranking the order of alternatives according to the increasing order of Q(A i ) (i = 1, 2, . . ., z). Remark 3. In the classical VIKOR [19], the attribute values are real numbers and the attribute weights and DM weights are known in priori, the group utility value and individual regret value are calculated through the subtraction of real numbers directly. However, the attribute values in this paper are TIFNs. To extend the VIKOR to suit the case of TIFNs, we firstly determine the attribute weights and DM weights objectively, and then utilize the defined distance of TIFNs to replace the subtraction of real numbers in the fractions of Eqs. ( 50) and (51). It is apparent that if the attribute values are reduced to real numbers, then the extended VIKOR method proposed in this paper is reduced to the classical VIKOR.

The above decision making process may be written as the following algorithm. (43). 5. Construct the TIFNs group decision matrix by using Eq. (44). 6. Normalize the group decision matrix by Eqs. (45) and (46). 7. Determine the positive and negative solutions by Eqs. ( 47) and (48). 8. Calculate the group utility value and individual regret value of each alternative by Eqs. ( 49) and (50). 9. Calculate the closeness of each alternative to the ideal solution Q(A i ) by Eq. (51). 10. Ranking the order of alternatives according to the increasing order of Q(A i ).

div.head: A personnel selection example and comparative analyses
div.p: To illustrate the proposed method in this paper, a department manager selection example is analyzed and the comparative analyses are also conducted in this section.

div.head: Personnel selection example
div.p: Suppose that an investment company desires to select a department manager, after preliminary screen, five candidates of A 1 , A 2 , A 3 , A 4 and A 5 remain for further evaluation. Four DMs of D 1 , D 2 , D 3 , and D 4 are employed to make decision, they assess the five candidates based on six attributes, including moral character a 1 , work attitude a 2 , leadership a 3 , cultural level a 4 , oral communication skill a 5 , and past experience a 6 . Assume that the total mark of each attribute is 10, the ratings of each candidate with respect to attributes are represented as TIFNs, listed in Tables 1234. The weight information of attributes and DMs are unknown completely, we need to determine the best candidate with the above given information.
Step 1: Without generality, take BUM function q(y) = y (r=1). According to Eq. ( 27), the crisp weighted possibility mean matrixes of DMs are obtained as in Table 5.

Step 2: Used Eqs. ( 28) and ( 29), the normalized possibility mean decision matrixes of DMs are obtained as in Table 6. According to Eqs. ( 30 Step 3: According to Eqs. ( 34) and ( 35), the weighted attribute evidence bodies m 0k j ðA i Þ of alternative A i on attribute a j given by D k are obtained and listed in Tables 78910.

By using Eq. ( 32), the Bayes approximation m 0k j ðA i Þ of mass function m 0k j ðA i Þ are obtained and listed in Tables 11121314. According to Eq. ( 36), the Bayes approximation m 0k j ðA i Þ ðj ¼ 1; 2; . . . ; 6Þ of alternative A i are aggregated into the individual overall evidence body m k (A i ) of alternative A i for DM D k as follows:
The evidence distance matrix between m q and m t (q, t = 1, 2, 3, 4) can be computed by using Eqs. ( 37 The evidence similarity matrix can be calculated by Eq. (39) as follows:
div.formula: 0 B B B @ 1 C C C A :
div.p: The support degree Sup (m k ) of m k can be calculated by Eq. (40) as follows:
div.formula: Supðm 1 Þ ¼ 2:9962; Supðm 2 Þ ¼ 2:9953; Supðm 3 Þ ¼ 2:9959; Supðm 4 Þ ¼ 2:9941:
div.p: Thus, the weight vector of DMs is obtained by Eqs. ( 41) and (42) as follows:
Step 4: The collective attribute weight vector can be calculated by Eq. ( 43) as follows:
Step 5: According to Eq. ( 44), the group decision matrix is obtained as in Table 15.
Step 6: Since the six attributes are all benefit attributes, by Eq. ( 45), the normalized group decision matrix is obtained as in Table 16.
Step 7: According to Eqs. ( 47) and ( 48), the positive ideal solution and negative ideal solution of the normalized group decision matrix are respectively obtained as follows:
div.formula: SðA 1 Þ ¼ 0:4348; SðA 2 Þ ¼ 0:4244; SðA 3 Þ ¼ 0:4499; SðA 4 Þ ¼ 0:4401; SðA 5 Þ ¼ 0:4726; RðA 1 Þ ¼ 0:1398; RðA 2 Þ ¼ 0:1317; RðA 3 Þ ¼ 0:1157; RðA 4 Þ ¼ 0:1263; RðA 5 Þ ¼ 0:1730: Thus,

div.p: Step 9: The closeness of each alternative to the ideal solution can be calculated by using Eq. (51).
Step 10: The closeness of each alternative to the ideal solution and the ranking order with different coefficient of decision mechanism k are obtained as in Table 17.

It is easy to see from Table 17 that the ranking orders of alternatives may be different as the coefficient of decision mechanism k takes different values. For example, when k = 0.5, DMs make decision by consensus, the ranking order is A 2 1 A 4 1 A 3 1 A 1 1 A 5 , thus the candidate A 2 is the best selection. The proposed method in this paper can simultaneously consider the maximum of group utility of the majority and minimum of the individual regret for the opponent. The DMs may choose different coefficients of decision mechanism (i.e., k) to make decision according to their own subjective preferences. Thus, the method proposed in this paper is of efficiency and flexibility.

div.head: Comparison analysis with the VIKOR method for the triangular fuzzy MAGDM
div.p: For the TIFNs in Tables 1234, suppose that all maximum membership degrees and minimum non-membership degrees are equal to 1 and 0, respectively, and then all TIFNs are degenerated into TFNs. Thus, the TIFNs in Tables 1-4 are changed into TFNs shown in Tables 18192021. The above personnel selection problem is degenerated to the MAGDM problem with TFNs.

Kuo and Liang [30] extended the VIKOR method for MAGDM problem with TFNs. We use the method [30] to solve the adapted personnel selection for further explaining the importance of using TIFNs to express the assessment information. Assume that the attribute weight vector and DM weight vector are w = (0.3108, 0.2083, 0.1984, 0.0177, 0.1407, 0.124) T and V = (0.25, 0.25, 0.25, 0.25) T , respectively. By using the method [30], we have

therefore, S + = 0.3498, S À = 0.6981, R + = 0.1344, R À = 0.2275. The collective comprehensive values of alternatives and ranking orders with different coefficients of decision mechanism k are obtained as in Table 22.
Therefore, although the coefficient of decision mechanism k takes different values, the ranking order of candidates obtained by the method [30] is

which is remarkably different from that obtained by the method proposed in this paper. This indicates that the maximum membership degrees and minimum non-membership degrees in TIFNs play a very important role in decision-making process indeed [5,6]. TIFNs have stronger ability to express uncertainty than TFNs, and can exquisitely depict the hesitation degrees inherent in the judgment of DMs. TIFNs may better reflect the assessment information of decision problems than TFNs by adding membership degrees and non-membership degrees. Compared with the method [30], the method proposed in this paper has the following advantages:

(i) This paper sufficiently considers the different importance of different DMs for their difference experience and knowledge. The weights of DMs are determined objectively by combining the evidence theory and Bayes approximation, which makes the decision results more consistent with the actual situation. Whereas Kuo and Liang [30] assumed that the weights of all DMs are the same and did not consider the different importance of DMs. (ii) According to the decision matrix information, this paper determines the attribute weights by Shannon entropy measure, while Kuo and Liang [30] utilized the transformation relationship between linguistic variable and triangular fuzzy number to give the attribute weights. Any transformation process between linguistic terms and fuzzy numbers may easily result in information losses and distortions to some degree. Hence, the method proposed in this paper is relatively more objective than the method [30].

div.head: Comparison analysis with the TIFN MADM method
div.p: When the decision group has only one DM, the MAGDM problem studied in this paper becomes MADM problem with TIFNs. Li [6] studied such MADM problems with TIFNs. The method proposed in this paper can also be used to solve the MADM problem studied in Li [6]. In the sequel, only single DM is considered, i.e., suppose the decision matrix is only given by D 1 and listed in

div.head: Table 17
div.p: The ranking orders of alternatives with different coefficients of decision mechanism.
div.formula: k Q(A 1 ) Q(A 2 ) Q(A 3 ) Q(A 4 ) Q(A 5 )
div.p: Ranking orders Best candidates 0.0 0.4200 0.2786 0 0.1846 1.0000 1. We use the methods proposed by Li [6] and this paper to respectively solve this MADM problem with TIFNs.

In the method [6] the attribute weight vector is give as W = (0.3108, 0.2083, 0.1984, 0.0177, 0.1407, 0.124) T in advance. The values of membership functions and non-membership functions of alternatives can be obtained as follows:
The ratios of the value index to the ambiguity index for the alternatives can be obtained as follows:
Thus, the ranking order of the five candidates by using the method [6] is generated as A 2 1 A 5 1 A 4 1 A 1 1 A 3 for k 2 [0, 0.6], A 2 1 A 5 1 A 3 1 A 4 1 A 1 for k 2 [0.7, 0.9].

In this paper the attribute weights are completely unknown, by using the Shannon entropy method, the attribute weight vector can be obtained as w = (0.3169, 0.2316, 0.1884, 0.017, 0.1205, 0.1257) T , and the group utility values and individual regret values are obtained as follows:
The ranking order of the five candidates by using the method proposed in this paper is A 1 1 A 3 1 A 2 1 A 4 1 A 5 for k 2 [0, 0.5], A 1 1 A 2 1 A 3 1 A 4 1 A 5 for k 2 [0.5, 0.9].

Obviously, the ranking orders of the five candidates obtained by Li [6] and this paper are remarkably different. On the one hand, this paper objectively determines the attribute weights by the entropy of decision matrix, while Li [6] artificially gave the attribute weights in advance and did not consider the determining method of the attribute weights. Giving different attribute weights maybe result in different ranking orders. Hence, the method proposed in this paper is more objective than the method [6]. On the other hand, the method proposed in this paper can be used to solve not only MAGDM problem but also MADM problem, whereas the method [6] is only appropriate for the MADM problem with TIFNs.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: This paper proposed a new method to effectively solve the MAGDM problems, in which the ratings of alternatives on attributes are expressed with TIFNs and the weights of attributes and DMs are completely unknown. Firstly, the crisp weighted possibility mean of TIFNs is defined and the Hamming and Euclidean distances for TIFNs are defined based on Hausdorff distance. The triangular intuitionistic fuzzy weighted average (TIF-WA) operator is developed. Then, the weights of attributes are calculated objectively by applying Shannon entropy measure and the weights of DMs are determined objectively combining the evidence theory with Bayes approximation. The individual decision matrixes for all DMs are aggregated into the group decision matrix by using the TIF-WA operator. Thereby, the classic VIKOR method is extended to solve the MAGDM with TIFNs. The extended VIKOR method enables DMs to achieve an acceptable compromise by balancing the maximum of utility for the majority and minimum of the individual regret for the opponent. The proposed method has clear concept, simple calculation and provides a new idea for solving MAGDM problems under intuitionistic fuzzy environment. The future work of this paper is to improve the aggregated algorithm and apply the proposed method to some other practical MAGDM problems, such as supply chain management, water resource schedule and so on.
